comments.content:
I believe that it is Andale Sans [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/andale-sans/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150105175955/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/andale-sans/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/andale-sans/") with the l trimmed.  
I recall discussions elsewhere that favored it as a DVD subtitle font.  
Don

I don't know if Steve Matteson [http://typophile.com/user/30401](http://web.archive.org/web/20150105175955/http:/typophile.com/user/30401 "http://typophile.com/user/30401") of ascendercorp.com still follows typophile discussions but IIRC he spoke of licensing the font for dvd subtitling.  
Don

Hmm, it looks close but the Q is distinctly different.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150105175955im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Q_3903.PNG)

Well, I don’t know whether to laugh or cry. I sent an email to Criterion asking about the font and here’s the response:

> Thanks for your email and interest! Criterion uses Arial Bold for subtitles, and also a proprietary font used by one of the subtitle houses we work with that closely resembles Arial. I hope this helps! Please feel free to write again if you have any other questions.
